fate: Hardware discontinued; software/services folded into Xbox Music (later Groove) and eventually retired.
summary: Microsoft’s digital media player line (2006–2012) known for Zune HD’s OLED screen and a subscription ‘Zune Pass.’ Hardware ended in 2011–2012 as Microsoft shifted to phone and streaming strategies.
overview_md:
**Zune** was Microsoft’s bid to rival the iPod with tightly integrated hardware, software, and the **Zune Pass** music subscription. Launched in **2006**, early Zunes emphasized Wi-Fi sharing and a bold UI; the **Zune HD** (2009) earned praise for its OLED display, capacitive touch, and snappy NVIDIA Tegra chipset. Despite a loyal following, Zune never reached iPod scale, and Microsoft wound down the hardware as it prioritized Windows Phone and, later, Xbox-branded music services.

In today’s climate, interest in **standalone music players** has ticked up again. Some listeners are frustrated that streaming fees keep rising and that access can vanish when licenses change—highlighting the difference between **renting** and **owning** music. Nostalgic Zune owners and new hobbyists alike value offline libraries, long battery life, and distraction-free listening. That doesn’t make Zune “current,” but it explains why refurbished units and modern DAPs see renewed attention: they restore a sense of collection ownership, predictable costs, and control over audio quality.

Zune’s design language—typography-forward, metro-influenced, and playful—left a mark on Microsoft UX. Its story is a time capsule of the shift from personal media libraries to cloud subscriptions, and the pendulum that occasionally swings back toward local files and dedicated devices.

timeline.text: First Zune (30 GB) launches in North America with Zune Marketplace and subscription option.
Second-gen Zunes (flash and 80 GB) ship with revised UI and wireless syncing.
Zune HD launches with OLED display, multitouch UI, and Tegra-based performance.
Microsoft confirms the end of Zune hardware production in favor of Windows Phone.
Zune software/services transition under Xbox Music branding (later Groove); Zune era effectively ends.
